definition: to look after/to take into consideration/to attend to

sentences.english: He frequents the commission sale store, hoping to fish out some bargain basement goods.
sentences.chinese: 他常光顾寄售商店，想捞点便宜货。

sentences.english: Thought Laotaibuxiao, still no one to patronize.
sentences.chinese: 没想老大不小，仍然没人光顾。

sentences.english: Members of the new and old customers to patronize, I will warmly for your service.
sentences.chinese: 欢迎各新老用户的光顾，我公司将热忱为你服务。

sentences.english: I go out of my way to patronize a dentist who has excellent communication skills.
sentences.chinese: 我经常光顾我的牙医，他有着高超的交流技巧。

sentences.english: Once or twice each year, snow and sleet move into the area.
sentences.chinese: 雪和冻雨每年要光顾这个地方一两次。

sentences.english: He could see down the plughole, so the sun must have shone.
sentences.chinese: 排水孔下面也看得见，一定是太阳光顾过。

sentences.english: He calls at every house in the street once a month.
sentences.chinese: 他每月一次，都要来这条街上光顾每一户人家。

sentences.english: This feeling of scarcity encourages customers to come to the stores and buy frequently.
sentences.chinese: 这种让大家觉得稀缺的感觉促使人们经常光顾和购买。

sentences.english: But many months went by and no one visited the island.
sentences.chinese: 可是一连许多月过去了，竟没有人来光顾这个岛屿。

sentences.english: Daniel, don't just drink you buttered tea.
sentences.chinese: 大牛，你别光顾着喝酥油茶。

sentences.english: The restaurant has a large patronage.
sentences.chinese: 光顾这家餐馆的人很多。

sentences.english: The restaurant is patronized by John.
sentences.chinese: 约翰经常光顾这家饭馆。
梁上君子经常光顾这些商店。

sentences.english: Herein, we sincerely welcome people from all social circles to our hotel.
sentences.chinese: 谨此，热情欢迎社会各届人士踊跃光顾。

sentences.english: The chic restaurant is patronized by many celeb rities.
sentences.chinese: 这家时髦的饭店常有名人光顾。

sentences.english: Many foreigners frequent that pub because of its homey atmosphere.
sentences.chinese: 那间酒吧有家的气氛，因此许多老外常会到那儿光顾。

definition: to come and go/to roam about (mostly unseen)/(of a ghost) to haunt (a place)/(of a criminal) to stalk (the streets)/(of the sun) to rise and set
to come to a place on account of its reputation (idiom); attracted to visit a famous location
to open a business/first transaction of a business day
to close a door/to lock a door/(of a shop etc) to close (for the night, or permanently)
thriving and prosperous business or trade
to roll/to wander around/to appear repeatedly
